I’ve been a DJ, a Producer, a Program Director, a Music Director, a Creative Services/Imaging Director, and ultimately a guy who does commercials for a living for a major company whose name I’m not going to mention…but it hasn’t been like that for all these years in a row.

In 2008, I get the opportunity to take my services to a radio station in the Boston area—being a born & bred Yankees fan, the experience was pretty intimidating enough; but over the next few years, I learned to adapt to life around New England, as well as being able to do my job in an environment that I wasn’t familiar with. I roll with whatever punches are thrown at me; and for the most part, I was living what I thought was a normal “Adult” life…………….And then, New Year’s Day of 2011 happened (give or take a few days). When I got in, one of my bosses asked me to come into his office; when I got there, I noticed that not just my boss (the Program Director) was in the room, but so was the General Manager and the Operations Director (read: the Finance guy). They begin to tell me that the station was going to be undergoing a format change to something that I actually had expertise in; Classic Hits (their previous format was “Light” music, AKA, “Audio Chloroform”). While that news excited me, the next piece of news absolutely gutted me—they then told me that in spite of all of the hard work that I put in there over 3 years, my services were to no longer be required by them.

In short, I got fired for the first time. To that point, I had exactly 3 jobs in my lifetime, and the first two I left because of the next opportunity being better than the last. But this was the first time IN MY LIFE no less, that I was full-fledged FIRED from my job…seemingly for no reason other than “Change for Change sake”. In fact, after I went home to my apartment that day, my IMMEDIATE thought was a famous quote that Harry Shearer said when he was fired from SNL under Dick Ebersol; citing “Creative Differences”, Shearer made the famed quip “I was Creative, they were different”…But before I could make that reflection, I pretty much went through the “5 Stages of Death”, but with a Workplace twist—First, I couldn’t believe that they would let me go despite actually doing (what I thought was) a reasonable job for them; to which they say that the decision was made “a long time ago”; Bullshit, but whatever. Next, I started getting angry about the whole thing; not in a “I’m gonna set the building on fire” kind of thing, but just enough to seethe and raise further questions—they just repeated that I was no longer required to work there. Next came fear…or in my case, breaking down in that office with choked up tears. My ex-bosses, in all their infinite wisdom, try to assure me that this would be for the best and that things like this happen all the time in a lot of walks of life—which is true to a point, but that just felt like rubbing salt in a wound at that juncture. The “Bargaining” step was made for me when they offered One Month’s Severance, and the “acceptance” step was me choking down my last tears to say to my bosses with as little emotion as possible, “Give me a Box, and Give me an hour”. I packed all my office knick-knacks up, and I left…unsure of what my next move would be…or where it would even take place.

The Next 3 years of (relative) unemployment would be one of the most harrowing experiences in my life…but the first 5 Months of that were probably the most unbearable period. Without getting too deep, let’s just say that the process of being approved for unemployment money AND Moving back to my home state was enough to hand-pluck all the hairs from my head. Unfortunately, I didn’t have the time to wait for/the experience to get another radio job, so I had very little choice but to live on the governmental dime for a little bit WHILE getting ready to move back home. On top of that, my car had been experiencing one problem after another; Leaky Radiator, failing alternator, snapped serpentine belt, fuel pump leak, Oxygen sensor malfunction, blown wiper blade motor—ALL Within the first 2 of those 5 months, and with little/no money to get things done. Fortunately, the unemployment money eventually kicked in—retroactively, no less, so that I’d have a decent cushion, and my problems were temporarily over…but I still felt miserable…VERY miserable, like “Bojack Horseman without the drugs or booze” miserable. Short of being forced to move back to New York, nothing really motivated me to do much of anything…I was faced with a situation that countless others have experienced before, but the fact that this was happening for the first time in my life just left me with a lot of anger, confusion, and frequent lunch stops/moments of reflection at my local Wendy’s.

Fast forward to May 2011; I’ve since moved back home and I have absolutely no idea what to do next, nor did I have much of a reason why I would even want to wake up each day. So whenever I get really depressed and I don’t want to add on to my waistline, I watch a lot of comedy movies and TV shows to help get my mind off of things. Mostly “classic” stuff; Gleason, Burnett, Sid Caesar, anything Norman Lear ever penned, and of course SNL—though more the earlier years than anything “Recent”; by this point in time, the show was trying to make up some lost ground after a dismal 35th year. But still, I watched the new stuff anyway because it remained one of the few constants in my life that would never fail me no matter how bad I was feeling or how bad the show was at the time. And for whatever reason, I really started gravitating towards the appearances Bill Hader would make as “Stefon”—The character itself would make a number of appearances long before my troubles began, but back then I just thought the pieces were just “OK”; nothing earth shattering, but still good enough to crack a grin……………But then came the Mother’s Day show that year, and the simple utterance of the word “SPICY!” I honestly can’t describe the chemical reaction behind it, but the moment Hader said “Spicy” the way that he did (followed, as usual, by Hader trying to keep it together), it garnered probably the biggest laugh that I have experienced in a very long time; it just felt incredibly satisfying to watch after being in an emotional pit for so long. Not only was I hooked on the character, but I would start feeling a little better about myself every time it was on—so much so, that not too long after that show aired, I decided to go back to college to complete my Bachelor’s degree after a lengthy hiatus.

It may seem a little hyperbolic to say that “Stefon” saved my sanity at that point, but the misery that I went through during those first few months was something I was more than willing to forget—and there are probably some parts that I left out on purpose either because I’ve repressed the shit out of them, or because they were moments that I wanted to forget. But any time Stefon was on the air during the next few years while I was going for my degree, it acted as a much needed shot in the arm whenever I needed to finish up an assignment, or if I just needed to smile a little extra. Stefon not only saved my sanity, but as you’ll see later in this list, He and I also “Graduated” around the same time; Both a little older and wiser, but more importantly; after giving me a lot of much needed laughs, I felt like I could take on the world again—after graduation and finding some odd jobs in the year after, I FINALLY got back into Radio in 2014, and I haven’t looked back since…and all because of “SPICY!” and the ability to laugh again…and If Bill Hader happens to find this blog by accident, I hope he realizes just how much the character meant to me—and I’m sure Millions of others—through the years, especially the rough ones…Thank you, Bill.

Now that I’ve got that off my chest, let me further remind you why Stefon Zolesky-Meyers is my favorite SNL character, and Bill Hader is one of my favorite SNL people…

…I’ve still got a job to do here, though. Just because it’s my favorite character doesn’t mean that it was “Perfect”…

HIS MOST RECENT APPEARANCE (3/17/2018) – Mojo labels this appearance as the character’s “Return”, but as you’ll see later on, the character has actually “Returned” a number of times, Including when Hader hosted in 2014. Nevertheless, I’ll let that slide since it was as funny as ever, including some instant classic one-liners, (“Moonlight, La La Land…”) and an ample use of a surprise Mulaney appearance. It didn’t miss a single beat. Maybe it’s because of how “recent” this was that Mojo ranks it at the bottom, but that’s understandable.

MOJO: 1

BLOG: 0

PUSH: 0

STEFON’S DEBUT (11/4/2008) – Now, if I’m going to be REALLY Honest, the first time the party boy made an appearance in sketch form, not only did I not quite “Get” the piece, but this also happened to air during a highly questionable time in SNL’s history. One where it seemed that every couple of weeks, there would be at least One sketch that had either inwardly or overtly Homosexual themes attached to it (*PUSHES “JERRY” BUTTON*). I will always be “Not Gay, but Supportive”, but it always kinda struck me odd that it would happen at critical mass around this time on the show—then again, this was also the year of the infamous “Prop 8” vote in California, so I guess I could see why they threw around a lot of Pro-Gay moments—no matter how poorly written they were. As for this sketch, I could kinda see why casual and Die-hard fans alike might’ve had a little trouble figuring this out the first time; but thanks to Hindsight, it’s really no different than any of the other appearances. Granted; the weirdness is there, but because Mulaney isn’t there to change the words on the cue cards at the last second, it feels like just another sketch—but at least the seeds of greatness were being planted here; so on that note, I give this one a Push because hindsight is fickle and nobody really knew what was coming next.

MOJO: 1

PUSH: 1

STEFON & ZOOLANDER (10/8/2011) – Speaking as someone who has always been “On The Fence” when it comes to Ben Stiller (Especially as an SNL Alum), I’ll be sure to give him a much needed dissection when the time is right; but for now, the fact that he would bring back a character that nobody heard from in 10 years was a bigger moment than any of the oddities that came out of Hader’s mouth that night. On the surface, Pairing Stefon with Zoolander makes all the sense in the world; “Vapid male model meets Party Boy, Hilarity ensues”, THAT should’ve been the Zoolander sequel instead of whatever convoluted mess they came up with—in fact, it wouldn’t surprise me if this appearance kickstarted the long dormant talk of making said disappointing sequel, so thank God for Small favors (I think?). Two things made Stiller’s appearance work better than it was supposed to; the location where his party was being held (SoWeHoBeLoHoboWo), and the fact that all proceeds benefitted a rather “Wordy” foundation whose name I won’t ruin here.

HALLOWEEN (10/20/2012) – Speaking of Halloween, I could’ve sworn the “Sidney Applebaum” joke was Much later in the character’s run; but considering how both he and Seth Meyers don’t age, it’s pretty easy to lose track (Just checked, Mojo screwed up the date, this was in 2012, NOT 2010). By this point in the proceedings, we weren’t 100% sure if Hader was going to leave the show yet or not—as this was his 8th year. Watching this again—and also realizing that we’d get one more appearance before his send-off that year—this felt like watching a “Greatest Hits” compilation, featuring such “Everythings” like Nick Nolte & Gabana, HoboCops, Bark Ruffalo, Little Israel, Frasins (Raisins that look like Frasier), human (“Fun Sized”) piñatas, and of course…MY SON! (To say nothing of the “Slimer” story at the end); But the big highlight to me is that we get a rare change of pace where we actually get a little insight to how Stefon spends some of his private time, not to mention Seth actually wanting to tag along to one of the parties without using his girlfriend as an excuse. Perhaps this was a sign of growth yet to come?

THE ACTUAL RETURN OF STEFON (10/10/2014) – Conveniently enough, I already mentioned this moment a while back. But since they are talking about one specific moment from the appearance, let’s dive a little deeper into that. For those too young to remember, Dan Cortese was what one called “an Actor”. But not just any actor, one that David Spade once tried to convince Evander Holyfield beat down before he retired (the first time). When he wasn’t doing stuff for MTV “Sports”, he was also known for Gen-X baiting Burger King Commercials in the early 90s. The fact that his name was dropped by Stefon Three times that night must’ve given Cortese not just a spring in his step, but enough phone calls to realize; “Wait a minute, Who would be calling Me?” Considering Cortese’s most recent acting role was nearly 4 years ago as per IMDB; perhaps “Three” isn’t as a magic a number as we once thought, but I’m sure he felt good about himself that night anyway.

“SPICY!” (5/7/2011) – C’mon guys, I just wrote a monologue about the moment! One additional thing I WILL say, however, is that Mojo got the date wrong…again. They have it as 2013, NBC’s website has it as 2011, and the 2 second clip of him just saying “Spicy!” is also from 2011. Nevertheless, let’s look at specifics; it opened 6 years into the future (2017), run by Rabbi “Jew Diamond Phillips”, and has everything from Geishas to Subway Sleeping Bags to (probably) a record number of giggle breaks from Hader…maybe that’s why I enjoy the moment so much; because even professionals need to be human?

SETH’S LAST UPDATE (2/1/2014) – I’m not sure if this moment should’ve been included. Yeah, Stefon does show up, but so do a whole slew of guest stars; and they’re each trying to take advantage of what few seconds they have on camera. The moment really belongs more to Seth than it did to anybody else—and this is despite Hader stealing the scene, as is his right. Tough call, but I gotta give this the ‘ol “Thumb’s Sideways”; Stefon was only there to wish Seth well—give or take a joke or two.

MOJO: 5

BLOG: 0

PUSH: 2

“……..KEVIN?” (3/10/2012) – So many great lines in this moment; “Opened at gunpoint at a lady Foot Locker”, club run by Blow J. Simpson, The “Sunny D” Fridge Spiel, and so forth. But by this point in the proceedings, you could tell that there may/may not have been something going on between Stefon & Seth; Seth resisting, Stefon egging him on—This, of course, leads to “The Kiss”; as well as countless fanfic being launched that night—only for Hader & Mulaney to catch up with everybody (See #1). Otherwise, This was probably the character at its peak…almost. Brushing up on my Shales/Miller, there’s a bit about how when Mick Jagger hosted the same year, Seth couldn’t even get through his intro without the crowd going nuts—and rightfully so, the character not only gained a following, but it kept getting bigger right to the end of the original run and beyond.

MOJO: 6

BLOG: 0

PUSH: 2

THE 40th ANNIVERSARY APPEARANCE (2/15/2015) – Another questionable inclusion; partly because SNL “Special” episodes (to me, anyway) are largely non-canonical, ESPECIALLY Anniversary shows—the few of them they had, anyway. That, and Edward Norton’s impression of Stefon just isn’t that great (in spite of Hader giving him pointers). I’ll give points for them carrying on with the idea that he & Seth are still “Married”, but this appearance was an otherwise extenuating circumstance.

MOJO: 6

BLOG: 1

PUSH: 2

HONORABLE MENTIONS:

“BOOOOOOFFFFFF” (2011) – I’m not sure if this is the first time a monosyllabic sound was used as the name of a club; but it must be significant enough to mention on the list. That aside, the name was just one funny part; but the club description didn’t disappoint either.

“YOUR MOTHER AND I ARE SEPERATING” (2013) – This one I Really liked because of just how “out of left field” Hader gets with his sudden voice change—not unlike “Spicy”. Switch this with the appearance from the 40th, and we’ll be OK.

MOJO: 7

BLOG: 2

PUSH: 2

1.STEFON’S WEDDING (5/17/2013) – Like I said at the top, Stefon and I “Graduated” around the same time…Literally; He moved up on a Saturday, while I moved up on a Sunday. I didn’t really think about it much back then because in the midst of all the hoopla and still not sure what my next move would be, when the day was done, I still had to write a review about the episode I recorded the night before (One that has sadly been lost to time and digital negligence). But the fact that I got my degree within hours of Hader getting one of the more memorable send-offs in show history seems sort of poetic in a way; Stefon felt whole again after “marrying” Seth, I felt whole again after completing my education. As for the moment itself, it was as much a funny one as it was Rewarding for those who are not only fans of the show, but those who really keep track of everything; as in “This Wedding had EVERYTHING”: Practically Every bizarre thing that Stefon has ever listed at New York’s hottest clubs—so much so, that watching it over and over just to see if they left anything out is a task in itself. Otherwise, off the top of my head, there were Human Traffic cones, Human Fire extinguishers, ALF in a Trench coat, a Furkel (Fat Urkel), a Coked out Gremlin, Menorah the Explorer, DJ Baby Bok Choy, and yes…not only Anderson Cooper as the jilted groom, but even Ben Affleck as Stefon’s Brother from the first sketch. So great was this moment, that I’ll go one step further and say that this would probably have been better as a stand-alone sketch instead of just as an Update Piece—Like, maybe end Update with Stefon storming out, then wait a few sketches before picking up on Seth in his Dressing room thinking about Stefon, and THEN do the Psychotropic “Graduate” parody, build suspense a little. Still though; as much as I enjoy the character making a comeback every once in a blue moon, this was the perfect way to have ended the character on a regular basis, as well as one hell of a payoff for the fans…………..Now if only we found out what that damn Tree Frog study was all about.

FINAL SCORE:

MOJO: 8

BLOG: 2

PUSH: 2

Right about now, you’re probably thinking that covering a list this “Personal” would’ve been a good way to end our Summer of Nitpicking…but the Summer isn’t over until the Calendar says it is; and I did have ONE more topic to look at before we place a bookmark in the Mojo tome and close it up (for now). So, for next week’s Misplaced Finale, we’re going to invoke the name of an infrequently recurring sketch from back in the 70s and wonder……………“What if…?”

MM: The Bonus Round

Let’s move on to a lighter subject, as well as one of my favorite non-SNL subjects…Game Shows.

And since this is another one of those lists where I need to compare notes on a previous list, we change the rules a little here. If any of Mojo’s picks wound up on My List, it’s immune from the “Blog” point since I would technically be agreeing with them, but the other two (Mojo or Push) are up for grabs. I also have a sneaky suspicion that there will be at least One “recurring” sketch in here, so we’ll deal with that as it comes. Now then, time for the lightning round…

WWTBAM WITH STEVE HARVEY (4/24/2010) – Sort of a gray area on this one; after all, Kenan Thompson’s impression has been used a number of times since this aired, so you could argue that it’s recurring…But those performances are largely for the “Family Feud” sketches (which we’ll get to in a moment). In this case, he’s doing the impression for a show that–while it’s still on the air–reached peak popularity around 2002. Therefore, it’s OK to judge this on its own merits…and considering that this was very much based on the Real Harvey’s actual hosting skills during the time he filled in for then-host Meredith Viera c2010, I have to award them the point on accuracy alone.
